segments.text: Well, this is Ron Shorn interviewing Bill Brunk in Washington, D.C. on October 13, 1993.
Bill, for the record, will you state your full name?
Okay, William Edward Brunk.
And when and where were you born?
I was born in Cleveland, Ohio on November 24, 1928.
When did you get interested in science or astronomy or engineering or whatever, technical things?
Actually, sort of as a side thing, I was interested in going to sea.
I wanted to go to the Naval Academy.
Was rejected by the Naval Academy after receiving an appointment because of a bad eye.
Went back to Case Institute of Technology.

because I had passed the entrance exam already for a case, having taken it to prepare for the Naval Academy entrance examination, and at that time all, which was 1946, everybody was coming back from the war, as the colleges were difficult to get into, and I finally got into a case in 1948 in civil engineering, graduated in mathematics,

While I was going to undergraduate school, the head of the astronomy department asked me who was John Jason Nassau, or Jason John Nassau, I guess, invited me to come and work at the observatory, for what reason I do not know.
Anyway, I did during my junior and senior years there, and when I graduated, he asked me what I was going to do with myself, and since I didn't know, he offered me an assistantship

at Case in the astronomy department to get my master's degree, and I did that and then went to work for NACA, and eventually NACA became NASA, and they were interested in astronomy, so they sent me back to get a Ph.D. at Case in astronomy.
So you were at what, Lewis Research Center?
I went to the Lewis Flight Propulsion Laboratory.
Okay, and what did you do while you were there?
I worked for a fellow by the name of George M. Lowe.
He was my section head.
And I worked on supersonic aerodynamics, both theoretical and laboratory.
What did you do your Ph.D. thesis on?
I did my Ph.D. thesis on peculiar and metallic line A-stars, trying to detect them with a Schmidt objective prism images.
And who did you do it under?
It was done under Jason Nassau.
All right.
So you got your PhD.
What happened then?
I got my PhD in 1963.
And in 1964, there was a need for somebody to come to NASA headquarters and take responsibility for programming planetary astronomy at NASA headquarters.
I was invited to do so by Dr. Erner Liddell, who was the chief scientist for the Lunar and Planetary Program at NASA headquarters.
Do you have any idea how he found you?
I understand later that he found me through Nancy Roman.
I had been on Nancy Roman's Astronomy Advisory Committee since 1958, I believe.
As the Lewis representative?
As the Lewis representative.
When you got to headquarters, as I recall, that was about the time that there was the first little crunch in funding.
And then your budget got bigger for a number of years.
Is that correct, or would you tell us what happened?
I was unaware of the initial crunch in funding because I was just coming in.
The numbers that I'd seen were so tremendous to me, more like a fortune than in French.
The budget did get bigger with time as planetary astronomy took on more and more importance.
I don't recall right at the moment when the first significant budget crunch came after that.
I'd have to look at the records.
There was one in 1973.
Well, that's ten years after I came.
Let me ask a more general question.
What do you think is the most important thing you did while you were headquartered?
I think the most important, well, it is a very difficult question to answer for a couple of reasons.
When I came to headquarters, it was the feeling of the division director, Mr. Oren Nix at that time,

that ground-based planetary astronomy had seen its better days and i was informed when i arrived here that he would like to say that he'd give me some sort of a permanent position here but all it could give me was a temporary position because planetary astronomy was just about terminated

Soon everything was going to be done from spacecraft, and there was going to be no need for anything to be done from the ground, and he was looking for somebody to come in and basically close out the program.
That, of course, never happened.
The importance of planetary astronomy, while low for a while there, became more and more significant and finally was
if I may say so, competitive with the planetary spacecraft.

And I think a lot of this was due to the fact that the instrumentation we had available, the techniques we had available, and the interest of the professional astronomers turned towards planetary observations.
When I came on board, it was very difficult to get anybody to make planetary observations.
and you'd go around almost begging people, if we give you some money in return for this, would you make an observation for us?
Well, this changed with some of the initial successes in the flight program.

It also changed not only because of that, but because instrumentation became available that we were able to turn onto planetary problems that people hadn't used for planetary problems before, and they suddenly
discovered that this was something that was scientifically interesting.

The other thing that happened, well, I would say therefore that the resurgence, or actually not a resurgence, but a genuine growth in planetary observations from the ground was probably one of the most exciting things that happened during the time I was here.
And I would say today, as has been true for probably the last 15 years or so,

the amount of research we can do in the planetary area or in the solar system area is limited more by the number of dollars we can put into it than by the people or the instrumentation that's available.
So it's still being a very productive aspect of the overall program.
The other thing that I was involved with, which went along with this but I think was also independently very valuable,
was the construction of major instrumentation throughout the country, opening up new sites that were not opened before.
And interestingly enough, it came about to a large extent because the National Science Foundation, who had been the primary financer of development of major instrumentation for

astronomy or for planetary well for all astronomy made i think an unwritten decision that they were going to focus their attention on certain locations and so the major instruments that they built they built in places like the kit peak and saratololo and the national radio astronomy observatory but they had a few specific locations that they invested
a large portion of their money in.
In the area of planetary astronomy, we had a different objective, and that is that we needed to get major telescopes at locations which were optimized for planetary observations.
Now, this had at least two aspects to it, possibly and probably even more.
One aspect to it was that we wanted to put telescopes where there were people who had strong interests in planetary observations.
And this led to the development of major telescopes in Texas, in Arizona, and a couple of other ones around.
Well, Hawaii came in for a different reason.
The other one was we wanted telescopes located for optimal planetary observations.
And getting as close to the equator made Hawaii an extremely important location.
In particular, when Mars is closest to the south of the celestial equator.
Right.
It's in the United States.
It is as close to the equator as we could get in a

available location and it was also separated from California and Texas by in longitude by significant distance and the advantage of this is that if you're looking at a planet which is a rotation period let's say similar to the earth or even one like Jupiter that doesn't have it similar you can see a different side of the planet from a site that's located at a sizable
difference in longitude.
Also, the weather patterns differ significantly enough so that you want to separate your telescopes significantly in longitude.
We have run planetary patrols where we've actually run telescopes in places like Australia and India, as well as in Hawaii and throughout the United States.
So longitude distribution is a very important thing in planetary observations.
ask you something that's a little out of whack here, but I don't want to miss it.
Two-part question.
Do you think planetary astronomy was considered second-rate astronomy by the, quote, astronomical establishment in the USA when you started, and do you think it still is?
The answer to both those questions is yes.
I think it has received a great deal of respectability
And it is now looked at with some considerable respect by many different types of astronomers.
But to many astronomers who are interested in stellar and galactic work, it's still considered a second-rate citizen.
The reason I asked that was your comment about trying to get people, you know.
Here's the money, will you observe?
And they turn you down.
I had exactly that experience.
Yes.
And it's frustrating as all get out.
Right.
And we had it for years.
Let me ask you two questions here, because there are two important people I can't interview.
One is Kuiper and one is Harlan Smith, and so I have to go around and ask people about them.
So let's start with the grand old man, Kuiper, Gerard Peter Kuiper.
What was he like?
Well, he talked a lot.
He talked a lot and had an unlimited number of ideas, many of which were not good, but many of which were very good.
And on the average, I think he had some wonderful ideas.
He was a great promoter.
He was a great seller of Gerard Kuiper.
He had unlimited interest in astronomy, but especially in planetary astronomy.
And he was a real salesman.
He was a real innovator.
Our whole reason for going over to Hawaii was Gerard Kuiper.
That was his idea originally, wasn't it?
Yes.
In fact, he did the first work on it.
How did he get frozen out of that?
When NASA decided to put a significant-sized telescope over in Hawaii,

gerard carper was very interested in doing it however there was some concern expressed that his empire was growing bigger than we felt that he could appropriately handle based to a large extent on the fact that we had worked with him in arizona he had built a telescope in arizona but he was his ideas were always going on and on new places new sites and we didn't think at that time that he might put as much
personal attention into the Hawaii telescope as we would like to see it have.
He wanted to operate it basically as a field station of Arizona, and he also wanted to use a relatively small telescope.
We were interested in a slightly larger telescope.
Here I'm talking the difference between something on the order of 82 inches versus, he was talking 60 inches.
He wanted to duplicate his Tucson telescope over in Hawaii.
At that time we also involved a fellow from Harvard, Don Menzel, in the possibility of operating a telescope in Hawaii.
How did you approach the University of Hawaii?
At the time they had no astronomers, they had some solar astronomers, which is a different world than we're used to.
How did that get going?
Did you do it, or did someone else do it, or what happened?
In those days, you must remember that most of the initiatives that took place were generated here.
Unlike the National Science Foundation, who responds to the community, NASA has always, or at least for a long time, been in the position of initiating programs.
And it was decided in NASA that we needed a major telescope at an excellent site separated in longitude and in weather pattern from the ones that were already available in Texas and in California.
Hawaii looked wonderful.
And it had the original tests on Hawaii that were made by Gerard Kuiper with his small telescope located over on Mauna Kea.
showed that that would be a very good site.
Also, he, Dr. Kuiper, did a very excellent job of selling Hawaii as a good site.
We then tried to figure out what would be the best approach in developing a site over there.
And as I said, we talked to Dr. Kuiper and we talked to Don Menzel at Harvard.

We also, when I say we here, it's not so much me, it's more Erna Liddell, called in John Jeffries from Hawaii, who although they had relatively little experience with telescopes at that time, were interested in getting involved in telescopes.
And John Jeffries, as you know, is also quite a good salesman.
And
The decision was made for several reasons, but mainly because we felt that Hawaii would place more personal interest in a telescope there than either Harvard or Arizona.
The decision was made to go with John Jeffries, because he was going to duplicate a Kitt Peak telescope
the 84-inch, and he was going to make use of people with some experience, like Hans Bosgaard and others who had had telescope building experience.
So we simply took a chance on him.
And it worked.
And it worked.
Let me ask you about another character, Harlan J. Smith.
What was Smithy like?
Well, Smith is also a tremendous salesman.

And when I came on board here, he had already talked Erna Liddell and maybe Ron Shorn and Roger Moore into having him duplicate a telescope at the University of Texas, a large telescope for planetary purposes.
And as was well known at that time, it was difficult to get people to make planetary observations.

And so the fact that somebody with some clout, some authority, and a great deal of interest and personal responsibility here saying, let me duplicate a telescope and put it here and use it primarily for planetary purposes at this, what appeared to be a very good site, was received eagerly.
back here at NASA headquarters.
And when I came on board, all the paperwork was already in motion for the telescope at the University of Texas.
To begin with.
No, it was a smaller telescope.
It was a smaller telescope.
Harlan found a blank.
A blank, 107-inch.
And that's the reason it went up to 107-inch.
It was originally 84-inch.

and basically it was going to be a duplicate of the one that was at kit peak same thing that uh john jeffries was going to do with hawaii and then harlan went wanted to go to a different mounting system and then he found the blank a much larger blank and came in and convinced in quotes us that it wasn't going to cost us any more money to build the larger telescope now
Harlan Smith, and I got this in black and white, but he said it many times in person, said the biggest mistake he ever made was that he had two bids.
One was for Bowler and Shivens, which was the higher bid initially.
It was a turnkey operation.
They delivered an operating working telescope.
And the other one was from Westinghouse, which was like a million dollars cheaper.
And he picked Westinghouse, and to his dying day, he regretted it as
I'm sure you still do to this day.
We still do to this day.
I was observing at McDonnell at the time a lot, and it must have been horrible for you.
Well, it was.
It was horrible, and the cost went way up on it.
And finally, we had to say, okay, we, NASA headquarters, are going to basically be the monitor on this telescope.
And it's unfortunate for Harlan, but we said, Harlan, we just can't leave it to you.
And what we did was, let's see, it was the vice chancellor at the University of Texas.
What was his name?
I forget it offhand.
No, let's see.
I know the dean of arts and sciences was John Silver, who is now president of BU, but this was the guy one step ahead, and I can't remember the name, but I can look it up.
And then he went into the whole system after that.
But basically, the difficulty is Harlan made all the original contracts.
We had all kinds of problems.
He had problems with Westinghouse.
Westinghouse had all kinds of problems.
The control system didn't work.
And so they said, and it was more or less saying, trust us, trust us, trust us.
We built nuclear submarines.
So we finally did two things.
We finally pushed it up above Harlan Smith at the University of Texas all the way up to the chancellor's office.
And the, I think it was Vice Chancellor, took personal interest in it and attended all reviews himself of the telescope at Westinghouse.
We then attended all reviews of the telescope at Westinghouse.
We made Westinghouse report on all activities on, it was at least six months, I think probably at that time, quarterly basis.
Harlan tells a story.
that at one time, basically, the shell of the telescope was laying in a pit at Westinghouse with nobody working on it.
Is that true?
Quite possibly.

But we tried to change the whole thing around and get Westinghouse to pay some attention to it, getting the highest concern at the highest levels of NASA, concerns at the highest levels of the University of Texas.
We had these status reviews at Westinghouse.
We had the top-level Westinghouse people there at Sunnyvale in on the reviews.
We went through all the problems.
They were open to all kinds of questions.
We questioned them everything, things that they didn't want to talk about.
We went through.
We had planned tours every so often.
We finally got it straightened out, but it was a real mess.
And the telescope came in way over cost.
I mean, like a million dollars over cost on the mountain.
In fact, it would have been cheaper to adopt the bowler in general.
Yeah, yeah.
It would have been a lot faster.
And we finally got it built.
It's working fine, but it was a headache to get it built.
And we decided at that time that if we ever did another telescope, we would do it in a different manner.
And we have done other telescopes in a completely different manner.
There was the Lake Lamentin.

attempt by JPL to get about a 60-inch telescope or something on Table Mountain, and I know I signed off on that darn thing, and I thought it was done, but it died lousy back in 65 or something like that.
Why did it die?
I mean, JPL people wanted it at the time.
We had, I guess, the biggest planetary astronomy group in the world.
What happened?
As I understand it, the thing that happened
was a disagreement between headquarters and Caltech.
And the people at JPL, which is, in effect, Caltech Sort of.
Well, that was one of the difficulties.
We would agree to build a telescope, as we did with all our telescopes, as an instrument, but not as a facility.
That meant that we would build the telescope, but not the building.
And this was being done through Caltech, not through JPL, because we did build many facilities through JPL.
We'd give them the telescope, but not the building.
They went to upper management here, went to Caltech, as I remember it, and said, look, we'll give you one facility.
Do you want the building for that telescope, or do you want a building on campus?"
Caltech said, we want the building on campus.
That was the end of the telescope.
I've also heard that Caltech was interested in building the perfect telescope at the perfect
in some indefinite future, whereas NASA obviously wanted to know things like what's the surface pressure on Mars, and Caltech could care less about that.
Is that true?
That aspect I don't remember at all.

All I know, and it was in the records when I got here, it was no longer an active program under consideration, so I personally didn't have anything to do with it, but it had been turned down because Caltech basically said, if that's our building, we don't want it.
Well, they had plenty of big, most of the big telescopes in the world already.
Yeah, and it was JPL that wanted the 60-inch telescope.
Let's get, and I'm confused here because the acronyms are ganging up on me, but you had a lot to do about an infrared telescope, and I forget what it's called, the IRTF?
Yeah, the IRTF.
Okay.
Back even in the 60s, there was all this talk about, in fact, that's one of the other
JPL wanted to do was to build an infrared light bucket, and they never did get one built in Table Mountain.
So that has a long story.
Can you summarize it in an hour or less?
Yes, there actually is a very good two-part report on that that came out in Science
and went into a great deal of detail in the background of the IRTF.
I had a copy of it around here someplace.
I don't know where it is.
But anyway, this was the thing.
We wanted to get a light bucket in the infrared, and that was, there was a, let's say there was a meeting.
By that you mean not a really superb primary mirror or something, just something to collect light and put it on a
Originally, the astronomers said what we want is a large aperture, large mirror light bucket for the infrared to make infrared observations of the planets.
What's his name?
Hugh Johnson at Arizona was building metal mirror telescopes, infrared light buckets.
Harold Johnson.
And in addition, there was one built at Caltech, Bob Layden.
I think Guido Munch was working with him on that one.
And at the time, of course, infrared detectors were very insensitive.
And they were doing an infrared sky survey.
But there was a lot of argument as to the value of infrared observations for planetary work.
Now, if you could get resolution, that was fine, but you didn't think you could get resolution.
There was a planetary astronomy study done at, oh, what's the name of that?
It was published in the early 1960s, and it was, I think, a location that the NSF had up in
New England someplace.
It wasn't Woods Hole.
It was another location.
I don't have a copy of the...
I have it packed away and my stuff is in storage, but I don't have a copy of it here.
But there was a group put together to look at the potential of planetary astronomy, ground-based planetary astronomy.
And one of the things they came up with was the
desirability of having an infrared telescope.
That generated our initial interest in infrared.
It was originally thought to be about a three-meter light bucket.
Then as things improved and detectors became better,
The concept changed from a three meter light bucket to a three meter higher quality instrument.
Although actually, when the IRTF was built, we didn't anticipate that the mirror was going to be as good as it was.
Now, there was also a desire to have it in the best possible location.
From the experience that we had in the infrared, it looked to us as if Hawaii, Mauna Kea, was probably the best site to put an infrared telescope.
So we started looking at Hawaii, and Jeffries had already built the 88-inch telescope.
We started looking at that site and the University of Hawaii to do an infrared telescope.
on Mauna Kea.

There was considerable concern expressed by the community outside of Hawaii that we were really not doing the appropriate analysis of capabilities and sites if we were going to build a major infrared telescope.
This resulted in a program
being undertaken, which we did site surveys.
I think we started out with about eight sites, ended up with something like five.
Jim Westfall at Caltech handled the actual site survey for us.
The sites included Mauna Kea, I think White Mountain, a site in Arizona.
There's a report that's out on it.
Again, it's filed away.
When I retired in 1985, some of these things I've got copies of, but they're all stored away, and I think NASA has copies of all the reports.
The things that were looked at were the water vapor content of the atmosphere above the site and something called infrared noise.
And I still think that they don't understand infrared noise.
We had infrared noise monitors that were designed by Jim Westfall, approved by Frank Lowe, and we did water vapor studies
And we did them for one full year at all of these sites.
A blind survey.
The data all came in by number, and the analysis were all made by number.
And it wasn't until the analysis were completed that the translation of the numbers into sites were known.
But it showed that, except for some unusual periods, the best location was Hawaii.
White Mountain looked very good, but unfortunately, due to weather, you couldn't do a continuous observation.
They had to keep pulling the observers off White Mountain.
So Mauna Kea became the site of favor, although many people argued that we were making a mistake by going to Hawaii because the cost of going up on the mountain there was very expensive.
The working conditions were very severe.
The number of legitimate planetary astronomers were less there, and so there was a lot of desire to go to a place like Arizona.

So I think in the actual priority rating by an outside committee that looked at all the results of the site surveys and every one of the people put in a proposal and they talked about logistics and the engineering support and the university support and everything else, they came up and rated Hawaii top
Arizona second, and then the other ones further on down the list.
We went to Hawaii.
We originally were going to build a fork mounting.
We did a couple of things.
One of them is we put together a committee of three people, Frank Lowell, Fred Gillette,
Neugebauer, Gary Neugebauer, to come up with the design of a telescope, rough design of a telescope.
They would like to have a polar mounting with a north pole and south pole.
Hawaii wanted to go with a fork.
Finally, Hawaii won out.
We went with the design of a fork.
However, the fork design could not be shown to satisfy the needs of the infrared observers, and we finally went with the polar mounting.
So you have enough room at the bottom end to mount their equipment and so forth?
It was stability more than anything.
Repeatability.
The example of a 120-inch
I mean, you have hysteresis and other serious problems.
You have flexure and gravitational deformation of the telescope mount.
And even though Charlie Jones, who did the design, tried to convince us that it would
There was enough question about it, so they changed the design to the other.
And that's important, because a lot of these infrared sources are not visible when you look through an eyepiece, so you've got to know where you're pointing.
You've got to know where you're pointing.
But there was another reason we finally changed the mount design.
It had nothing to do with the mount.
It had to do with a cracked mirror.

And the problem that we had there was, in an attempt to save money, NASA came up with a mirror that had been purchased for testing, not for the space telescope, but for testing, for figuring out the space telescope mirror.
And we were given that mirror.
and we're going to use it for the IRTF.
Unfortunately, on the grinding table at Kitt Peak, for one holiday, it developed a crack, and we were forced to go to another replacement mirror.
Being forced to go to the replacement mirror
provided us with an unexpected additional amount of time to finish the telescope, which was enough time to change the design of the mount.
You might say, why this particular concern?
We were trying to finish the IRTF in time to make measurements of the satellites of Jupiter and Saturn
and of the planets themselves prior to the launch of the Voyager spacecraft.
That was probably the main driver on the telescope schedule.
When the mirror cracked, we were no longer able to meet that schedule.
And even though there were some questions about the design of the mount prior to that,
the desire to meet that schedule, because we had promised Congress that we were going to meet that schedule, said, OK, maybe the design mount won't work.
But to meet the schedule, we'll go with it.
When the mirror cracked and we had to go back and replace the mirror and start over again, that gave us a forced delay in the schedule.
that forced delay in the schedule was sufficient to allow us to go back and redesign the mount of the telescope.
Who was the managing institution for the IRTF?
University of Hawaii?
University of Hawaii.
And who runs it now?
How is it run now?
Okay, it is still run by the University of Hawaii under contract to NASA.
It is a NASA facility, completely a NASA facility.
NASA owned and
but operated for us by the University of Hawaii under a contract.
Now, here's a question that has three parts, but it's really only one.
As I recall, one of the deals that Texas got was that they were going to devote a substantial fraction of time on what became the 107-inch to planetary observing.
But the 88-inch at Hawaii and the 107-inch
McDonald and the IRTF were funded by NASA.
What fraction of time do they have to give to NASA or planetary observers?
I don't remember the specific fraction of time, but it was something on the order of 30 percent of the time on the telescope had to be made available for guest observers.
that was people that were not associated with the institution that had the telescope.
Now it's very important to say that the approach used for both the 107-inch at Texas and the 88-inch in Hawaii were quite different than that used for the IRTF.
In both the Texas and smaller Hawaii telescope,

we nasa provided money to build the instrument not the building and not the dome they were specifically excluded in return for paying for the instrument in all aspects of the instrument although we couldn't pay for the piers that was part of the building but paying for the instrument plus assuring that we would provide

funding for the operation of the telescope, it was agreed that a significant amount of time on the telescope would be used for planetary studies, and something on the order of 30 percent of the time would be made available to observers from other institutions.
We could not take government money and give it to one institution.
They basically had to operate a facility that was available part of the time for other things.
I think it may be, and you'd have to check me on this, but my memory says that the agreement was that they would do planetary research for something like 30% of the time.
We would pay them something like 30% of the operating costs of the telescope, plus providing them with a telescope in the first place.
And a certain fraction of that 30% had to be used by non-institution people.
In the case of the IRTF, that was from the start to the finish a NASA instrument.
Instrument, building, dome, piers, all NASA.
100% NASA.
We paid the full operating cost of that telescope and continue to do so.
But in return for operating it for us,
The University of Hawaii gets something like 25% of the time on the telescope.

The division of observing time between planetary and non-planetary, or let's say solar system and non-solar system, since we include other things other than just the planets now, is decided by NASA in advance.
And it has been something like 50-50.
But NASA reserves the right to increase or decrease, as it wishes, the amount of time on solar system observations.
But it has to do so in advance.
Now, NASA is the sole funder of the IRTF, with one exception.
And that is that the National Science Foundation said to NASA

If you say you're going to operate this as a national facility, which is what NASA says it is doing, we want you to provide subsidies for the observers similar to those we provide at Kitt Peak, Cerro Tololo, NRAO, et cetera.
We said, fine.
But much of the time is going to be spent making observations that are not of interest to NASA.
The NSF said, fine.
We will provide the subsidy funding for travel, things like this, for the time not used for NASA programs, if you provide a similar amount for NASA programs.
So every year, we get a small amount of money from NSF to provide subsidy to the people working on programs not of interest to NASA.
Let me change the subject here and ask you something that's purely an opinion.
Back at the turn of the century, planetary astronomy was a respectable subject.
By 1930, it was not popular, in fact, even dangerous to be in, according to people like Fred Whipple.
What do you think killed it?
I think the thing that killed it was the fact that we had just about reached the limit of what could be done with the instrumentation that was available back at the turn of the century.
We had got just about every piece of information we could except for just continuing looking at changing in surface appearance of the planets and things like this.
What happened to change it was that when planetary astronomy went out of favor, instrumentation development was still taking place.
And very few people use these new developments to look at the planets.
And in fact, when I came on board in 64,
We were still trying to get people to use basically standard techniques for stellar astronomy to look at the planets.
